text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: RMediation R package computing confidence intervals (CIs) nonlinear functions model parameters (e.g., indirect effects) single-level multilevel structural equation models. provides parametric, semiparametric, non-parametric methods confidence interval estimation, emphasis exact distribution theory robust bootstrap procedures.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Provide researchers flexible, statistically rigorous tools quantify mediation mechanisms maintaining accessibility applied practitioners. Methods accommodate observational studies experimental designs.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Tofighi & MacKinnon (2011): RMediation foundational CI methods Tofighi (2020): MBCO bootstrap methods (Frontiers Psychology) MacKinnon et al. (2007): PRODCLIN distribution product (Behavior Research Methods) Craig (1936): Frequency function product two normals

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses GitHub Actions CI/CD workflows defined .github/workflows/: - r.yml: R package check macOS R versions 3.6.3 4.1.1 - lintr.yml: Code linting - codeql.yml: Security analysis

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Minimum R version: 3.5.0 (specified DESCRIPTION) Roxygen2: Use roxygen2 documentation (current: 7.2.3) Functional approach: Vectorize operations; avoid loops possible Clarity priority: Code must readable methodologists applied users

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package currently uses camelCase snake_case mixed conventions: Functions: - Main exports use camelCase: medci(), qprodnormal(), pprodnormal() - Internal helpers use camelCase lowercase prefix: medciMeeker(), medciMC(), medciAsymp() - Formula interface uses lowercase: quant parameter Arguments: - mu.x, mu.y path coefficient estimates (path, b path) - se.x, se.y standard errors - rho correlation coefficients (default: 0) - type CI algorithm: “dop”, “mc”, “asymp”, “” - alpha significance level (default: 0.05) - n.mc Monte Carlo sample size Note: adding new functions, maintain consistency existing naming patterns codebase.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package three main user-facing functions distinct internal implementations: Dispatches : medciMeeker(), medciMC(), medciAsymp() Located : R/medci.R Implements distribution product method via Meeker & Escobar (1994) algorithm Dispatches : confintMC() confintAsymp() Located : R/ci.R Accepts lavaan objects raw mu/Sigma inputs Uses formula interface (quant parameter) specifying functions Multivariate delta method asymptotic SE Dispatches : mbco_asymp(), mbco_parametric(), mbco_semi() Located : R/mbco.R Works OpenMx models (h0 h1) Implements bootstrap variants hypothesis testing

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package implements distribution functions product two normal random variables: Internal implementations: pprodnormalMeeker(), pprodnormalMC(), qprodnormalMeeker(), qprodnormalMC() Located : R/pprodnormal.R, R/qprodnormal.R General purpose function coefficients Located : R/pMC.R, R/qMC.R

title: CLAUDE.md
text: lavaan: SEM parameter extraction (coef(), vcov()) OpenMx: mbco() model-based optimization tests MASS: mvrnorm() multivariate normal sampling doParallel/foreach: parallel bootstrap computations MBCO tests e1071: skewness/kurtosis calculations

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Located : data/ Used examples mbco() function

title: CLAUDE.md
text: product two normals (*b), analytical SE formula (Craig, 1936) : implemented consistently across methods except MC ’s computed empirically.
code: SE = sqrt(se.y^2 * mu.x^2 + se.x^2 * mu.y^2 + 2*mu.x*mu.y*rho*se.x*se.y + se.x^2*se.y^2 + se.x^2*se.y^2*rho^2)

what: CI Method Types and When to Use Them
title: CLAUDE.md
text: Default medci() Uses Meeker & Escobar (1994) algorithm exact distribution theory accurate small samples; computationally intensive Assumes joint normality coefficient estimates Use : Accuracy matters speed Default ci() Generates samples multivariate normal, computes empirical quantiles Flexible works complex functions (via ci() formula interface) Accuracy increases n.mc (default: 1e5 medci(), 1e6 ci()) Use : Need flexibility complex mediation models multiple paths Uses delta method approximation Fast often underestimates CI width Assumes normality; questionable small samples Use : Quick approximation needed; recommended inference Returns results applicable methods Useful comparing method robustness plot=TRUE, superimposes distributions different methods

title: CLAUDE.md
text: medci() ci() support visualization: - plot=TRUE: Displays density plot sampling distribution - plotCI=TRUE: Overlays confidence interval error bars (requires plot=TRUE) - type="", superimposes distributions different methods

title: CLAUDE.md
text: mbco() function tests H₀: indirect effect = 0 via constrained optimization bootstrap refinement: Types: - “asymp” (default): Asymptotic MBCO chi-squared test - “parametric”: Parametric bootstrap - resamples asymptotic normal distribution MLEs (efficient, relies model specification) - “semi”: Semiparametric bootstrap - resamples data re-estimates models (robust misspecification, computationally intensive) OpenMx Optimization: - Default optimizer: “SLSQP” - Falls back SLSQP NPSOL unavailable - Precision: 1e-9 default functional precision - Arguments checkHess checkSE default “” speed Usage pattern:
code: # Define full and null models in OpenMx full_model <- mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent=TRUE) null_model <- mxTryHard(null_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent=TRUE) mbco(h0=null_model, h1=full_model, type="asymp")

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Generally holds large n Central Limit Theorem Questionable small samples (n < 50) extreme parameters Diagnostic: Q-Q plots resampled coefficients bootstrap Default rho=0 assumes independence α̂ β̂ Reality: Often correlated shared confounders Non-zero ρ widens confidence intervals Important: Always check rho specified covariance matrix Beyond package’s scope critical causal interpretation Package computes CIs conditional specified model Validity depends research design causal assumptions Especially critical parametric bootstrap mbco() Semiparametric bootstrap robust misspecification

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Ignoring ρ ≠ 0: Can lead overly narrow CIs Small samples asymptotic method: Normal approximation breaks Effects near zero: CIs may highly asymmetric; interpret cautiously Assuming statistical significance implies causal mediation: Always consider design confounding

title: CLAUDE.md
text: MC method medci() ci() follows pattern: Generate samples bivariate/multivariate normal distribution using MASS::mvrnorm() Compute products (arbitrary function via formula ci()) Extract empirical quantiles α/2 1-α/2 Report MC error: SE estimate = SD(products) / sqrt(n.mc) Memory considerations: - Default n.mc=1e5 medci() (two-variable case) - Default n.mc=1e6 ci() (general case) - large covariance matrices: length(mu) * n.mc must < .Machine$integer.max - exceeded, n.mc automatically reduced 1e6 warning Reproducibility: - Set seed calling reproducible results - MC error reported assess convergence

title: CLAUDE.md
text: implementing new CI method: Create internal function signature: Add dispatcher main function (medci() ci()) Write unit tests known examples Document assumptions function documentation Benchmark accuracy speed existing methods
code: .ci_new_method <- function(mu.x, mu.y, se.x, se.y, rho, alpha) {   # Returns list with: CI, Estimate, SE   list(     CI = c(lower, upper),     Estimate = estimate,     SE = se   ) }

title: CLAUDE.md
text: ci() function can accept lavaan fitted objects directly: pattern extended adding support SEM packages.
code: # Extract from lavaan if (isa(mu, "lavaan")) {   pEst <- coef(fm1)                    # Parameter estimates   name1 <- all.vars(quant)              # Extract variable names from formula   mu <- pEst[name1]                     # Subset to relevant parameters   covM1 <- vcov(fm1)                    # Covariance matrix   Sigma <- covM1[name1, name1]          # Subset covariance }

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Compare published examples (MacKinnon et al. 2007, Tofighi & MacKinnon 2011) Verify consistency: DOP ≈ MC large n.mc Check asymptotic CIs narrower DOP/MC (known behavior) Parametric vs semiparametric equivalence correct model specification Convergence increasing bootstrap samples Reproducibility set.seed() Small sample size (n < 50) small indirect effects (near zero) High correlation ρ (near ±1) Near-singular covariance matrices Extreme SE values (numerical stability) Verify identical coefficients lavaan object vs manual input Handle different lavaan model types (sem, cfa, growth) Proper extraction constrained parameters Invalid type argument alpha outside (0, 1) rho outside (-1, 1) Mismatched dimensions mu Sigma Non-positive-definite covariance matrices

title: CLAUDE.md
text: bootstrap methods, empirical coverage within Monte Carlo error: - 95% CI contain true value ~93-97% time simulations - Lower coverage indicates method failure assumption violation

title: CLAUDE.md
text: simple mediation (X → M → Y): : - α = effect X M - β = effect M Y (controlling X) - ρ = correlation α̂ β̂
code: Indirect effect = α × β + ρ·SE(α)·SE(β)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Simplified ρ = 0:
code: SE(αβ) = sqrt(β²·SE(α)² + α²·SE(β)² + 2αβρ·SE(α)·SE(β) + SE(α)²·SE(β)² + SE(α)²·SE(β)²·ρ²) SE(αβ) = sqrt(β²·SE(α)² + α²·SE(β)² + SE(α)²·SE(β)²)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: z₁₋α/₂ normal quantile (e.g., 1.96 95% CI) Warning: often underestimates CI width product distribution normal.
code: CI = (αβ) ± z₁₋α/₂ × SE(αβ)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Craig, C. C. (1936). frequency function xy. Annals Mathematical Statistics, 7(1), 1-15. MacKinnon, D. P., Fritz, M. S., Williams, J., & Lockwood, C. M. (2007). Distribution product confidence limits indirect effect: Program PRODCLIN. Behavior Research Methods, 39(3), 384-389. Meeker, W. Q., & Escobar, L. . (1994). algorithm compute CDF product two normal random variables. Communications Statistics-Simulation Computation, 23(1), 271-280. Tofighi, D., & MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43(3), 692-700. Tofighi, D. (2020). Bootstrap Model-Based Constrained Optimization Tests Indirect Effects. Frontiers Psychology, 10, 2989. Tofighi, D., & Kelley, K. (2020). Indirect effects sequential mediation models: Evaluating methods hypothesis testing confidence interval formation. Multivariate Behavioral Research, 55(2), 188-210.

text: Shiny web application Monte Carlo CI: https://amplab.shinyapps.io/MEDMC/

title: Authors and Citation
text: Davood Tofighi. Author, maintainer.

title: RMediation
text: RMediation provides rigorous statistical methods mediation analysis observational experimental designs. addresses known limitations normal-theory confidence intervals (e.g., Sobel test) implementing advanced methods account non-normal distribution indirect effect.

title: RMediation
text: Compute accurate Confidence Intervals (CIs) indirect effects using methods outperform standard normal approximation: Distribution Product: Exact method product two normal random variables. Monte Carlo Method: Robust simulation-based intervals. Bootstrapping: Parametric semi-parametric bootstrap implementations.

title: RMediation
text: LRT-MBCO: Implements Likelihood Ratio Test via Model-Based Constrained Optimization, powerful frequentist method testing indirect effects controls Type error rates better standard approaches. Sobel Test: Asymptotic normal test included baseline comparison.

title: RMediation
text: Works directly summary statistics (coefficients/SEs). Extracts parameters automatically fitted lavaan OpenMx model objects.

title: RMediation
text: can install stable version CRAN: development version GitHub: R
code: install.packages("RMediation") # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("data-wise/RMediation")

what: Using Summary Statistics to Calculate CIs
title: RMediation
text: already estimates published paper software, can calculate CIs using coefficients (̂,b̂\hat{}, \hat{b}) standard errors.
code: library(RMediation)  # Example: Single mediator # a = 0.5, b = 0.6, se.a = 0.08, se.b = 0.04, rho = 0 (independence) medci(mu.x = 0.5, mu.y = 0.6, se.x = 0.08, se.y = 0.04, rho = 0, type = "prodclin")

what: Using ci to Calculate CIs for Indirect Effects of Path with Two Sequential Mediators
title: RMediation
code: library(RMediation)  # Example: Two sequential mediators ci(mu = c(b1 = 1, b2 = .7, b3 = .6, b4 = .45),   Sigma = c(.05, 0, 0, 0, .05, 0, 0, .03, 0, .03),   quant = ~ b1 * b2 * b3 * b4, type = "MC", plot = TRUE, plotCI = TRUE)

title: RMediation
text: Contributions welcome! encounter issues feature requests: Report Bug Submit Pull Request

title: RMediation
text: use RMediation research, please cite following: Package Reference: > Tofighi, D., & MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692–700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x MBCO Method: > Tofighi, D., & Kelley, K. (2020). Improved inference mediation analysis: Introducing model-based constrained optimization procedure. Psychological Methods, 25(4), 496-515. doi:10.1037/met0000259 Bootstrap MBCO: > Tofighi, D. (2020). Bootstrap Model-Based Constrained Optimization Tests Indirect Effects. Frontiers Psychology, 10, 2989. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02989

title: RMediation
text: RMediation licensed GPL-3.0.

what: RMediation: Mediation Analysis Confidence Intervals — RMediation-package
title: RMediation: Mediation Analysis Confidence Intervals — RMediation-package
text: Computes confidence intervals nonlinear functions model parameters (e.g., product k coefficients) single-level multilevel structural equation models. Methods include distribution product, Monte Carlo simulation, bootstrap methods. also performs Model-Based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) procedure hypothesis testing indirect effects. References: Tofighi, D., MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692-700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x ; Tofighi, D., Kelley, K. (2020). Improved inference mediation analysis: Introducing model-based constrained optimization procedure. Psychological Methods, 25(4), 496-515. doi:10.1037/met0000259 ; Tofighi, D. (2020). Bootstrap Model-Based Constrained Optimization Tests Indirect Effects. Frontiers Psychology, 10, 2989. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02989 .

title: RMediation: Mediation Analysis Confidence Intervals — RMediation-package
text: Maintainer: Davood Tofighi dtofighi@gmail.com (ORCID)

what: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci
title: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci
text: function returns (\(1-\alpha\))% confidence interval (CI) well–defined nonlinear function coefficients single–level multilevel structural equation models. ci function uses Monte Carlo (type="MC") asymptotic normal theory (type="asymp") multivariate delta standard error (Asymptotic–Delta) method (Sobel, 1982) compute CI. addition, methods, user specifies plot=TRUE plotCI=TRUE, plot sampling distribution quantity interest quant argument overlaid plot CI produced. type="" plot=TRUE, two overlaid plots sampling distributions corresponding method produced; plotCI=TRUE, overlaid plots CIs methods displayed well.

title: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci
code: ci(   mu,   Sigma,   quant,   alpha = 0.05,   type = "MC",   plot = FALSE,   plotCI = FALSE,   n.mc = 1e+06,   H0 = FALSE,   mu0 = NULL,   Sigma0 = NULL,   ... )

title: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci
text: mu (1) vector means (e.g., coefficient estimates) normal random variables. user can assign name mean value, e.g., mu=c(b1=.1,b2=3); otherwise, coefficient names assigned automatically follows: b1,b2,.... , (2) lavaan object. Sigma either covariance matrix vector stacks columns lower triangle variance–covariance matrix one underneath . quant quantity interest, nonlinear/linear function model parameters. Argument quant formula must start symbol "tilde" (~): e.g., ~b1*b2*b3*b4. names coefficients must conform names provided argument mu default names, .e., b1,b2,.... alpha significance level CI. default value .05. type method used compute CI. takes values "MC" (default) Monte Carlo, "asymp" Asymptotic–Delta, "" produces CIs using methods. plot TRUE, plot approximate sampling distribution quantity interest using specified method(s) argument type. default value FALSE. type="", superimposed density plots generated methods displayed. plotCI TRUE, overlays CI plot error bars density plot sampling distribution quant. type="", superimposed CI plots generated methods added density plots. Note obtain CI plot, one must also specify plot="TRUE". default value FALSE. n.mc Monte Carlo sample size. default sample size 1e+6. H0 False. TRUE, estimate sampling distribution \(H_{0}:f(\bm b)=0\). See arguments mu0 Sigma0. mu0 vector means (e.g., coefficient estimates) normal random variables satisfy null hypothesis \(H_{0}:f(\bm   b)=0\). provided, smallest z value mu zet zero. Sigma0 either covariance matrix vector stacks columns lower triangle variance–covariance matrix one underneath . provided, Sigma used instead. ... additional arguments.

title: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci
text: type "MC" "asymp", ci returns list contains: (\(1-\alpha\))% CI vector lower upper confidence limits, Estimate point estimate quantity interest, SE standard error quantity interest, MC Error type="MC", error Monte Carlo estimate. type="", ci returns list two objects, list contains results produced method described .

title: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci
text: Tofighi, D. MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692–700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x

title: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci
text: Davood Tofighi dtofighi@gmail.com

title: CI for a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — ci

what: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test — mbco
title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test — mbco
text: function computes asymptotic MBCO chi-squared test smooth function model parameters including function indirect effects.

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test — mbco
code: mbco(   h0 = NULL,   h1 = NULL,   R = 10L,   type = "asymp",   alpha = 0.05,   checkHess = "No",   checkSE = "No",   optim = "SLSQP",   precision = 1e-09 )

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test — mbco
text: h0 OpenMx model estimated null hypothesis, constrained model h1 OpenMx model estimated alternative hypothesis, less constrained model. usually model hypothesized researcher. R number bootstrap draws. type 'asymp' (default), asymptotic MBCO chi-squares test comparing fit h0 h1. 'parametric', parametric bootstrap MBCO chi-squared test computed. 'semi', semi-parametric MBCO chi-squared computed. alpha Significance level default value .05 checkHess '' (default), Hessian matrix calculated. checkSE '' (default), standard errors calculated. optim Choose optimizer available OpenMx. default optimizer "SLSQP". optimizer choices available. See mxOption details. precision Functional precision. default value set 1e-9. See mxOption details.

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test — mbco
text: list contains chisq asymptotic chi-squared test statistic value df chi-squared df p chi-squared p-value computed based method specified argument type

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test — mbco
text: Davood Tofighi dtofighi@gmail.com

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test — mbco
code: data(memory_exp) memory_exp$x <- as.numeric(memory_exp$x)-1 # manually creating dummy codes endVar <- c('x', 'repetition', 'imagery', 'recall') manifests <- c('x', 'repetition', 'imagery', 'recall') full_model <- OpenMx::mxModel(  "memory_example",  type = "RAM",  manifestVars = manifests,  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = "x",    to = endVar,    arrows = 1,    free = TRUE,    values = .2,    labels = c("a1", "a2", "cp")  ),  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = 'repetition',   to = 'recall',   arrows = 1,    free = TRUE,    values = .2,    labels = 'b1'  ),  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = 'imagery',  to = 'recall',  arrows = 1,  free = TRUE,  values = .2,  labels = "b2" ), OpenMx::mxPath(  from = manifests,  arrows = 2,  free = TRUE,  values = .8 ), OpenMx::mxPath(  from = "one",  to = endVar,  arrows = 1,  free = TRUE,  values = .1 ), OpenMx::mxAlgebra(a1 * b1, name = "ind1"), OpenMx::mxAlgebra(a2 * b2, name = "ind2"), OpenMx::mxCI("ind1", type = "both"), OpenMx::mxCI("ind2", type = "both"), OpenMx::mxData(observed = memory_exp, type = "raw") ) #> Warning: Looks like there is a pre-existing one-headed path from 'x' to 'x'. #> That path is now overwritten by a two-headed path between 'x' and 'x'. #> To retain the one-headed path, either use 'dummy' latent variables, or directly modify the MxModel's 'A' matrix; #> See the `mxPath()` help page for examples. #> Be advised, this overwriting behavior may change in the future, so do not write scripts that rely upon it! ## Reduced  Model for indirect effect: a1*b1 null_model1 <- OpenMx::mxModel( model= full_model, name = "Null Model 1", OpenMx::mxConstraint(ind1 == 0, name = "ind1_eq0_constr") ) full_model <- OpenMx::mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent = TRUE ) #>  Beginning initial fit attempt Fit attempt 0, fit=5637.33872082209, new current best! (was 86655.7966682804) Final run, for Hessian and/or standard errors and/or confidence intervals                                                                               #>  #>  Solution found!  Final fit=5637.3387 (started at 86655.797)  (1 attempt(s): 1 valid, 0 errors) null_model1 <- OpenMx::mxTryHard(null_model1, checkHess=FALSE, silent = TRUE ) #>  Beginning initial fit attempt Fit attempt 0, fit=5637.39905321693, new current best! (was Inf) Final run, for Hessian and/or standard errors and/or confidence intervals                                                                           #>  #>  Solution found!  Final fit=5637.3991 (started at 86655.884)  (1 attempt(s): 1 valid, 0 errors) mbco(null_model1,full_model) #> $chisq #> [1] 0.06033239 #>  #> $df #> [1] 1 #>  #> $p #> [1] 0.8059713 #>

what: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
text: Produces confidence intervals mediated effect product two normal random variables

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
code: medci(   mu.x,   mu.y,   se.x,   se.y,   rho = 0,   alpha = 0.05,   type = "dop",   plot = FALSE,   plotCI = FALSE,   n.mc = 1e+05,   ... )

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
text: mu.x mean \(x\) mu.y mean \(y\) se.x standard error (deviation) \(x\) se.y standard error (deviation) \(y\) rho correlation \(x\) \(y\), -1 <rho < 1. default value 0. alpha significance level confidence interval. default value .05. type method used compute confidence interval. takes values "dop" (default), "MC", "asymp" "" plot TRUE, plots distribution n.mc data points distribution product two normal random variables using density estimates provided function density. default value FALSE. plotCI TRUE, overlays confidence interval error bars plot mediated effect. Note obtain CI plot, one must also specify plot="TRUE". default value FALSE. n.mc type="MC", n.mc determines sample size Monte Carlo method. default sample size 1E5. ... additional arguments passed function.

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
text: vector lower confidence limit upper confidence limit. type "prodclin" (default), "DOP", "MC" "asymp", medci returns list contains: (\(1-\alpha\))% CI vector lower upper confidence limits, Estimate point estimate quantity interest, SE standard error quantity interest, MC Error type="MC", error Monte Carlo estimate. Note type="", medci returns list four objects, list contains results produced method described .

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
text: function returns (\(1-\alpha\))% confidence interval mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain confidence interval using specific method, argument type specified. default type="dop", uses code wrote R implement distribution product coefficients method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach compute confidence interval (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="asymp" produces asymptotic normal confidence interval. Note except Monte Carlo method, standard error indirect effect based analytical results Craig (1936): $$\sqrt(se.y^2 \mu.x^2+se.x^2 \mu.y^2+2 \mu.x \mu.y \rho se.x se.y+   se.x^2 se.y^2+se.x^2 se.y^2 \rho^2) $$. addition, estimate indirect effect \(\mu.x \mu.y +\sigma.xy \); type="" prints confidence intervals using four options.

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
text: Craig, C. C. (1936). frequency function \(xy\). Annals Mathematical Statistics, 7, 1–15. MacKinnon, D. P., Fritz, M. S., Williams, J., Lockwood, C. M. (2007). Distribution product confidence limits indirect effect: Program PRODCLIN. Behavior Research Methods, 39, 384–389. Meeker, W. Escobar, L. (1994). algorithm compute CDF product two normal random variables. Communications Statistics: Simulation Computation, 23, 271–280. Tofighi, D. MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692–700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
text: Davood Tofighi dtofighi@gmail.com

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect — medci
code: ## Example 1 res <- medci(   mu.x = .2, mu.y = .4, se.x = 1, se.y = 1, rho = 0, alpha = .05,   type = "dop", plot = TRUE, plotCI = TRUE ) #> Warning: 'length', 'angle', or 'code' greater than length 1; values after the first are ignored  ## Example 2 res <- medci(mu.x = .2, mu.y = .4, se.x = 1, se.y = 1, rho = 0,  alpha = .05, type = "all", plot = TRUE, plotCI = TRUE) #> Warning: 'length', 'angle', or 'code' greater than length 1; values after the first are ignored

what: Memory Experiment Data Description from MacKinnon et al., 2018 — memory_exp
title: Memory Experiment Data Description from MacKinnon et al., 2018 — memory_exp
text: Data obtained eight replicated experiments. data collected first day class part first Dr. MacKinnon's (2018) classroom teaching. pedagogical value experiment students first-hand knowledge experiment thereby increasing understanding course concepts. Permission use data obtained university Institutional Review Board.

title: Memory Experiment Data Description from MacKinnon et al., 2018 — memory_exp
code: data(memory_exp)

title: Memory Experiment Data Description from MacKinnon et al., 2018 — memory_exp
text: data frame 369 rows 5 variables: study Replication ID, ranges 1 8 repetition Use repetition rehearsal technique 1 9 scale recall Total words recalled 20 words imagery Use imagery rehearsal technique 1 9 scale x factor two levels: repetition primary rehearsal = 0, imagery secondary rehearsal = 1

what: Probability (percentile) for the Monte Carlo Sampling Distribution of a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — pMC
title: Probability (percentile) for the Monte Carlo Sampling Distribution of a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — pMC
text: function returns probability corresponding quantile q.

title: Probability (percentile) for the Monte Carlo Sampling Distribution of a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — pMC
code: pMC(q, mu, Sigma, quant, lower.tail = TRUE, n.mc = 1e+06, ...)

title: Probability (percentile) for the Monte Carlo Sampling Distribution of a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — pMC
text: q quantile mu vector means (e.g., coefficient estimates) normal random variables. user can assign name mean value, e.g., mu=c(b1=.1,b2=3); otherwise, coefficient names assigned automatically follows: b1,b2,.... Sigma either covariance matrix vector stacks columns lower triangle variance–covariance matrix one underneath . quant quantity interest, nonlinear/linear function model parameters. Argument quant formula must start symbol "tilde" (~): e.g., ~b1*b2*b3*b4. names coefficients must conform names provided argument mu default names, .e., b1,b2,.... lower.tail logical; TRUE (default), probability \(P[quant < q]\); otherwise, \(P[quant > q]\) n.mc Monte Carlo sample size. default sample size 1e+6. ... additional arguments.

title: Probability (percentile) for the Monte Carlo Sampling Distribution of a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — pMC
text: scalar probability value.

title: Probability (percentile) for the Monte Carlo Sampling Distribution of a nonlinear function of coefficients estimates — pMC
text: Tofighi, D. MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692–700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x

what: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
text: Generates percentiles (100 based quantiles) distribution product two normal random variables mediated effect

title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
code: pprodnormal(   q,   mu.x,   mu.y,   se.x = 1,   se.y = 1,   rho = 0,   lower.tail = TRUE,   type = "dop",   n.mc = 1e+05 )

title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
text: q quantile value product mu.x mean \(x\) mu.y mean \(y\) se.x standard error (deviation) \(x\) se.y standard error (deviation) \(y\) rho correlation \(x\) \(y\), -1 <rho < 1. default value 0. lower.tail logical; TRUE (default), probability \(P[X*Y < q]\); otherwise, \(P[X*Y > q]\) type method used compute confidence interval. takes values "dop" (default), "MC", "asymp" "" n.mc type="MC", n.mc determines sample size Monte Carlo method. default sample size 1E5.

title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
text: object type list contains following values: p probability (percentile) corresponding quantile q error estimate absolute error

title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
text: function returns percentile (probability) associated error distribution product mediated effect (two normal random variables). obtain percentile using specific method, argument type specified. default method type="dop", based method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product two normal random variables. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="" prints percentiles using three options. method type="dop", error modulus absolute error numerical integration (information see Meeker Escobar, 1994). type="MC", error refers Monte Carlo error.

title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
text: Tofighi, D. MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692–700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x

title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
text: Davood Tofighi dtofighi@gmail.com

title: Percentile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — pprodnormal
code: pprodnormal(q = 0, mu.x = .5, mu.y = .3, se.x = 1, se.y = 1, rho = 0, type = "all") #> $`Distribution of Product` #> [1] 0.4548488 #>  #> $`Monte Carlo` #> [1] 0.45464 #>

title: Quantile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — qprodnormal
text: p probability mu.x mean \(x\) mu.y mean \(y\) se.x standard error (deviation) \(x\) se.y standard error (deviation) \(y\) rho correlation \(x\) \(y\), -1 <rho < 1. default value 0. lower.tail logical; TRUE (default), probability \(P[X*Y < q]\); otherwise, \(P[X*Y > q]\) type method used compute confidence interval. takes values "dop" (default), "MC", "asymp" "" n.mc type="MC", n.mc determines sample size Monte Carlo method. default sample size 1E5.

title: Quantile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — qprodnormal
text: object type list contains following values: q quantile corresponding probability p error estimate absolute error

title: Quantile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — qprodnormal
text: function returns quantile associated error (accuracy) corresponding requested percentile (probability) p distribution product mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain quantile using specific method, argument type specified. default method type="dop", uses method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product two normal variables. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="" prints quantiles using three options. method type="dop", error modulus absolute error numerical integration (information see Meeker Escobar, 1994). type="MC", error refers Monte Carlo error.

title: Quantile for the Distribution of Product of Two Normal Variables — qprodnormal
code: ## lower tail qprodnormal(   p = .1, mu.x = .5, mu.y = .3, se.x = 1, se.y = 1, rho = 0,   lower.tail = TRUE, type = "all" ) #> $`Distribution of Product` #> [1] -0.9898408 #>  #> $`Monte Carlo` #> [1] -1.000082 #>  ## upper tail qprodnormal(   p = .1, mu.x = .5, mu.y = .3, se.x = 1, se.y = 1, rho = 0,   lower.tail = FALSE, type = "all" ) #> $`Distribution of Product` #> [1] 1.433771 #>  #> $`Monte Carlo` #> [1] 1.439503 #>

text: Davood Tofighi dtofighi@gmail.com

title: Creates a data.frame for a log-likelihood object — tidy.logLik
code: fit <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars) logLik_fit <- logLik(fit) tidy(logLik_fit) #>            term  estimate df #> 1 logLikelihood -80.01471  3

title: RMediation 1.3.0 (2025-11-18)
text: Updated functions package documentation. Updated package dependencies. Updated mbco function documentation. Implemented checkmate robust input validation. Created GitHub pages package documentation. Refactored package structure better organization. Refactored package validation better input validation. Added tests package functions.

title: RMediation 1.2.3 (5/12/2023)
text: Fixed issue type=“” medci function generate incorrect labels CIs.

title: RMediation 1.2.2 (5/11/2023)
text: CRAN release: 2023-05-12 Fixed issue type=“” medci function generate error “object ‘MeekerCI’ found”. changed dependency version grDevices >= 3.5 description file.

title: RMediation 1.2.1 (4/28/2023)
text: CRAN release: 2023-05-03 Fixed issues meet CRAN submission requirements.

title: RMediation 1.2.0 (6/28/2022)
text: CRAN release: 2022-07-08 New parametric non-parametric MBCO test, using mbco function.  Fixed error printing medci, ‘(1-alpha)% CI’

title: RMediation 1.1.5 (6/7/2020)
text: Fixed issue ‘medic’ function printed ‘(1-alpha/2)% CI’ instead ‘(1-alpha)% CI’

title: RMediation 1.1.4 (3/12/2016)
text: CRAN release: 2016-03-14 ‘medci’ function output structure changed. ‘type’, produces ‘list’ ‘(1-alpha/2)% CI’, ‘Estimate’, ‘SE’. See help(ci) information. Two functions ‘pMC’ ‘qMC’ added. medci(), type=‘prodclin’ replaced ‘dop’.

title: RMediation 1.1.3
text: CRAN release: 2014-03-07 New ‘ci’ function produces CIs well-defined function parameter estimates SEM MSEM using Monte Carlo asymptotic normal theory multivariate delta standard error method.
